occurrences.line_text: She is the mighty Queene of Faerie,
She is the flowre of grace and chastitie,
My whole desire hath beene, and yet is now,
Whereby her course is stopt, and passage staid.
Soone it must turne to earth; no earthly thing is sure.
How is it, that this mood in me ye blame,
She is the fountaine of your modestee;
You shamefast are, but Shamefastnesse it selfe is shee.
And likest is vnto that heauenly towre,
And all that fained is, as leasings, tales, and lies.
Weake body well is chang'd for minds redoubled forse.
Therefore he Anamnestes cleped is,
Vneath is to assure; vneath to wene
And Debons shayre was, that is Deuonshyre:
But true it is, that when the oyle is spent,
But true it is, that when the oyle is spent,
The light goes out, and weeke is throwne away;
That loue is not, where most it is profest,
That loue is not, where most it is profest,
And built that gate, which of his name is hight,
Yet true it is, that long before that day
Her Host two hundred thousand numbred is;
He is againe vnto his rule restord,
Receiued is to grace and new accord,
How brutish is it not to vnderstand,
Their force is fiercer through infirmitie
No wretchednesse is like to sinfull vellenage.
Is setled there in sure establishment;
That is each thing, by which the eyes may fault:
Likewise that same third Fort, that is the Smell
Against the fourth Bulwarke, that is the Tast,
Like swine; for so deformd is luxury,
So feeble is mans state, and life vnsound,
Sith now he is farre from his monstrous swarme,
That is the Gulfe of Greedinesse, they say,
On th'other side an hideous Rocke is pight,
May backe returne, but is condemned to be drent.
What now is left of miserable wights,
But by the way, there is a great Quicksand,
For she is inly nothing ill apayd,
This is the Port of rest from troublous toyle,
Worse is the daunger hidden, then descride.
Is sweet, and pleasing vnto liuing sense,
That is our Selfe, whom though we do not see,
For here the end of all our trauell is:
For all that pleasing is to liuing eare,
Gather therefore the Rose, whilest yet is prime,
Gather the Rose of love, whilest yet is time,
Sith it is shrined in my Soueraines brest,
faire Florimell is chaced:
So is his angry courage fairely pacifyde.
To get a snatch, when turned is his face.
That faithfull is, and better were to die.
All losse is lesse, and lesse the infamie,
Taketh his nimble wings, and soone away is gone.
That she is fairer, then our fairest Dame,
Perdie (said Britomart) the choise is hard:
That truth is strong, and trew loue most of might,
Is in a noyous cloud enueloped,
With thousand blessings she is heried;
Such loue is hate, and such desire is shame.
Such loue is hate, and such desire is shame.
For great rebuke it is, loue to despise,
All my delight on deedes of armes is set,
Far fro my natiue soyle, that is by name
For hardy thing it is, to weene by might,
Ne soothlich is it easie for to read,
So is his soueraine honour raisde to heauens hight.
Hart that is inly hurt, is greatly eased
Hart that is inly hurt, is greatly eased
And sith it is vneath to find his haunt,
In Deheubarth that now South-wales is hight,
Sorrow is heaped in thy hollow chest,
Is not enough, that I alone doe dye,
But mine is not (quoth she) like others wound;
It is, ï¿½ Nurse, which on my life doth feed,
Nor Prince, nor pere it is, whose loue hath gryde
Nor man it is, nor other liuing wight;
Though strange beginning had, yet fixed is
Th'vneuen number for this businesse is most fit.
But loue, that is in gentle brest begonne,
Nor herbes, nor charmes, nor counsell, that is chiefe
To Maridunum, that is now by chaunge
It is an hideous hollow caue (they say)
The cause some say is this: A litle while
And housed is within her hollow brest,
Ne is thy fate, ne is thy fortune ill,
Ne is thy fate, ne is thy fortune ill,
The spouse of Britomart, is Arthegall:
Yet is no Fary borne, ne sib at all
Ne other to himselfe is knowne this day,
But sooth he is the sonne of Gorlois,
And for his warlike feates renowmed is,
Nay but the terme (said he) is limited,
Tho when the terme is full accomplishid,
But yet the end is not. There Merlin stayd,
Ah read, (quoth Britomart) how is she hight?
Is throwne on the Rich strond:
Faire Florimell of Arthur is
Where is the Antique glory now become,
If they be dead, then woe is me therefore:
Wherein my feeble barke is tossed long,
So feeble is the powre of fleshly arme.
Deare image of my selfe (she said) that is,
Is this thine high aduauncement, ï¿½ is this
Is this thine high aduauncement, ï¿½ is this
Ne of thy late life memory is left,
But who that liues, is left to waile his losse:
So life is losse, and death felicitie.
Is built of hollow billowes heaped hye,
For Tryphon of sea gods the soueraine leach is hight.
Thy dwelling is, in Herebus blacke hous,
(Blacke Herebus thy husband is the foe
For light ylike is loth'd of them and thee,
And sheweth each thing, as it is indeed:
Truth is his daughter; he her first did breed,
Our life is day, but death with darknesse doth begin.
She, she it is, that hath me done despight:
Wonder it is to see, in diuerse minds,
Yet she her selfe is whiter manifold:
Is, that she is the fairest wight aliue, I trow.
Is, that she is the fairest wight aliue, I trow.
Ah dearest God (quoth he) that is great woe,
But Dwarfe aread, what is that Lady bright,
That Lady is (quoth he) where so she bee,
And is ycleped Florimell the faire,
Yet she loues none but one, that Marinell is hight.
A Sea-nymphes sonne, that Marinell is hight,
Of my deare Dame is loued dearely well;
All her delight is set on Marinell;
He is yslaine, which is the ground of all our woe.
He is yslaine, which is the ground of all our woe.
The heauy plague, that for such leachours is prepard.
Mercy deare Lord (said he) what grace is this,
Vnthankfull wretch (said he) is this the meed,
Faire death it is to shonne more shame, to dy:
Of Amoret is told.
That is ingenerate in fleshly slime.
As it in antique bookes is mentioned.
Is rightly cald, th'author of life and light;
So my delight is all in ioyfulnesse,
To scorne the ioy, that Ioue is glad to seeke;
For he is faire and fresh in face and guize,
And called is by her lost louers name,
Are fetcht: there is the first seminarie
And euery sort is in a sundry bed
Yet is the stocke not lessened, nor spent,
That substance is eterne, and bideth so,
But chaunged is, and often altred to and fro.
The substance is not chaunged, nor altered,
For euery substance is conditioned
Is wicked Time, who with his scyth addrest,
For all that liues, is subiect to that law:
But were it not, that Time their troubler is,
There is continuall spring, and haruest there
Yet is eterne in mutabilitie,
In a strong rocky Caue, which is they say,
Like to a ghost, that lately is reuiued
And loue to frenzy turnd, sith loue is franticke hight.
So strong is passion, that no reason heares.
Or on the marble Pillour, that is pight
And is the spectacle of ruinous decay.
That Geauntesse Argante is behight,
That Geauntesse, is not such, as she seemed,
And deedes of armes aboue all Dames is deemed,
And aboue many knights is eke esteemed,
For her great worth; she Palladine is hight:
But she, or such as she, that is so chaste a wight.
But read, thou Squyre of Dames, what vow is this,
Is sought by Paridell.
Villein (said he) this Ladie is my deare,
The driest wood is soonest burnt to dust.
Hard is to teach an old horse amble trew.
Where be ye now, when she is nigh defild
But sith that none of all her knights is nye,
Proteus is Shepheard of the seas of yore,
Like as a fearefull Partridge, that is fled
His bowre is in the bottome of the maine,
Therein is eaten out an hollow caue,
Is the late ruine of proud Marinell,
Emongst the rest my lot (vnworthy) is to be one.
Thy labour all is lost, I greatly dread,
That Ladies safetie is sore to be drad:
For lo in heauen, whereas all goodnesse is,
But all his mind is set on mucky pelfe,
Yet is he lincked to a louely lasse,
But he is old, and withered like hay,
That is the cause, why neuer any knight
Is suffred here to enter, but he seeme
A womans will, which is disposd to go astray.
It is not yron bandes, nor hundred eyes,
Then is he not more mad (said Paridell)
Is not empierst with deepe compassiowne,
But a third kingdome yet is to arise,
It Troynouant is hight, that with the waues
Of wealthy Thamis washed is along,
That it a wonder of the world is song
And Ouert gate by North: that is the bound
His worke great Troynouant, his worke is eke
Fond is the feare, that findes no remedie;
All that is by the working of thy Deitee.
That is the father of fowle gealosy,
Then now, that noble succour is thee by,
That is the whole worlds commune remedy.
Then sighing sore, It is not long (said he)
Fame is my meed, and glory vertues pray.
For litle good of him is to be got,
Then all the world is lost, and we in vaine haue toyld.
Then is it best (said he) that ye doe leaue
Ne euer is he wont on ought to feed,
Is woxen so deform'd, that he has quight
Forgot he was a man, and Gealosie is hight.
Where he is shrowded in security.
Why then is Amoret in caytiue band,
Why then is Busirane with wicked hand
My Lady and my loue is cruelly pend
That all the sorrow in the world is lesse,
Must not here thinke to liue: for life is wretchednesse.
And said; Sir knight, your cause is nothing lesse,
Then is your sorrow, certes if not more;
More is more losse: one is enough to dy.
More is more losse: one is enough to dy.
Life is not lost, (said she) for which is bought
Life is not lost, (said she) for which is bought
Endlesse renowm, that more then death is to be sought.
Inglorious and beastlike is: therefore Sir knight,
Aread what course of you is safest dempt,
This is (quoth he) the dolorous despight,
What is there else, but cease these fruitlesse paines,
And take me for their Ioue, whiles Ioue to earth is gone.
Yet loue is sullein, and Saturnlike seene,
Of persons flockt, whose names is hard to read:
Is death, or if that ought do death exceed,
Now cease your worke; to morrow is an holy day.
By which fraile youth is oft to follie led,
For it of honor and all vertue is
And best is lou'd of all aliue I weene:
To her this song most fitly is addrest,
By way of sport, as oft in maskes is knowen,
And now she is with her vpon the way,
All is his iustly, that all freely dealth:
Is creasted all with lines of firie light,
Hard by the gates of hell her dwelling is,
It is a darksome delue farre vnder ground,
But none to issue forth when one is in:
For discord harder is to end then to begin.
For life it is to her, when others sterue
That whether were more false, full hard it is to tell.
Ne for light Ladies loue, that soone is lost.
Such is thy wont, that still when any Knight
Is weakned, then thou doest him ouerronne:
An hideous storme, is by the Northerne blast
Whose chiefe desire is loue and friendly aid
For Loue is free, and led with selfe delight,
Sweare she is yours, and stirre vp bloudie frayes,
Is wicked discord, whose small sparkes once blowen
Such Musicke is wise words with time concented,
That by themselues vnto themselues is wrought,
So blind is lust, false colours to descry.
And euer when his passion is allayd,
Where is my part then of this Ladie bright,
And that which is for Ladies most befitting,
And of them all she that is fayrest found,
And of those Knights who is most stout on ground,
Since therefore she her selfe is now your ward,
For vertue is the band, that bindeth harts most sure.
Oppressed her, and there (as it is told)
The hideous Chaos keepes, their dreadfull dwelling is.
His line, which is the eldest of the three,
Which is of them the shortest, as I see,
Yet is as nigh his end, as he that most doth playne.
Like an old Oke whose pith and sap is seare,
But when the floud is spent, then backe againe
Is often seene full freshly to haue florisht,
And drawne it was (that wonder is to tell)
Nepenthe is a drinck of souerayne grace,
Is this, then that same water of Ardenne,
Wonder it is that sudden change to see:
But he shall haue the Hag that is ybet,
Against the Turneiment which is not long.
That fairest is and from her faith will neuer swerue.
For last is deemed best. To her therefore
Sweete is the loue that comes alone with willingnesse.
What is your owne, that I mote you requite?
But what is he, by whom ye shamed were?
Yet is not this the first vnknightly part,
That is the crowne of knighthood, and the band
What is of her become, or whether reft,
Vaine is the art that seekes it selfe for to deceiue.
That pittie is to heare the perils, which she tride.
Selfe to forget to mind another, is ouersight.
Vntride, is lesse then when thou shalt it try:
Death is to him, that wretched life doth lead,
Is this the faith, she said, and said no more,
Which for it is too long here to abide,
And is by Arthure slaine.
That the displeasure of the mighty is
That when your pleasure is to deeme aright,
Her nature is all goodnesse to abuse,
Sith now of dayes such temperance is rare
And now it is so vtterly decayd,
Yet hath he left one daughter that is hight
But ah she giuen is to vaine delight,
Which keeper is this Dwarfe, her dearling base,
Hard is the doubt, and difficult to deeme,
And quenched is with Cupids greater flame:
But sooth is said, and tride in each degree,
Whose right she is, where euer she be straide,
Is now so well accorded all anew;
Great Venus Temple is describ'd,
And yet such grace is giuen them from aboue,
Yet is the paine thereof much greater then the fee.
No tree, that is of count, in greenewood growes,
The temple of great Venus, that is hight
Nor all that else through all the world is named
By her the heauen is in his course contained,
She is the nourse of pleasure and delight,
She syre and mother is her selfe alone,
Ne ought on earth that merry is and glad,
Ne ought on earth that louely is and fayre,
Thou art the root of all that ioyous is,
Marinells former wound is heald,
She lenger yet is like captiu'd to bee:
(This Tryphon is the seagods surgeon hight)
Now hight Palemon, and is saylers frend;
Into old Gall, that now is cleeped France,
Was slaine: but that which is th'immortall spright
Proud Priams towne. So wise is Nereus old,
In which her kingdomes throne is chiefly resiant.
He doth adorne, and is adorn'd of it
Is cal'de Blacke water, and the Liffar deep,
And count my cares, when none is nigh to heare,
Is farre from hearing of my heauy plight;
Is hardned more with my aboundant teares.
That blame it is to him, that armes profest,
One prison fittest is to hold vs two:
Know Marinell that all this is for thee.
Like as an Hynde whose calfe is falne vnwares
Ne weene what mister maladie it is,
Or loue forbid him, that is life denayd:
Read therefore who it is, which this hath wrought,
To whom she answerd, Then it is by name
Me seemes the world is runne quite out of square,
Is now cald vice; and that which vice was hight,
Is now hight vertue, and so vs'd of all:
Right now is wrong, and wrong that was is right,
Right now is wrong, and wrong that was is right,
Is wandred farre from where it first was pight,
Ne is that same great glorious lampe of light,
But is miscaried with the other Spheres.
He is declyned from that marke of theirs,
Faith may be giuen, it is by them told,
But most is Mars amisse of all the rest,
Whose soueraine powre is herein most exprest,
Whose glorie is to aide all suppliants pore,
And is the Virgin, sixt in her degree,
Ah woe is me, and well away (quoth hee)
The which another did, who now is fled with shame.
That hence so long departed, is but vaine:
Is lightly stricken with some stones throw;
To witnesse to the world, that she by him is dead.
True loue despiseth shame, when life is cald in dread.
Nought is more honorable to a knight,
Is he, that doth to trauellers such harmes?
He is (said he) a man of great defence;
Whose scalp is bare, that bondage doth bewray,
His name is hight Pollente, rightly so
For that he is so puissant and strong,
Which is but narrow, but exceeding long;
That is both swift and dangerous deepe withall;
Her name is Munera, agreeing with her deedes.
Thereto she is full faire, and rich attired,
In whose right hands great power is contayned,
For ere thou limit what is lesse or more
Or faile thereof, so much is more then iust to trow.
All change is perillous, and all chaunce vnsound.
Doe eate the earth, it is no more at all:
Ne is the earth the lesse, or loseth ought,
Is with the tide vnto an other brought:
For there is nothing lost, that may be found, if sought.
Likewise the earth is not augmented more,
What wrong then is it, if that when they die,
For all we haue is his: what he list doe, he may.
What euer thing is done, by him is donne,
What euer thing is done, by him is donne,
Which is (sayd he) more heauy then in weight,
For truth is one, and right is euer one.
For truth is one, and right is euer one.
There Braggadochio is vncas'd
Is not (I wager) Florimell at all;
As he with golden saddle is arayd;
For vaine it is to deeme of things aright,
For powre is the right hand of Iustice truely hight.
Full true it is, what so about our land
Your right is good (sayd he) and so I deeme,
Your brothers threasure, which from him is strayd,
Your right is good (sayd he) and so I deeme,
And so the threasure yours is Bracidas by right.
Is falne on you, by heauens hard direction,
Is for the sake of Bellodant the bold,
Vppon that gibbet, which is there behind,
And made her famous, more then is belieued;
And is subdewd by guile:
He is by her emprisoned,
Like one that from his dreame is waked suddenlye.
No fayrer conquest, then that with goodwill is gayned.
In womans weedes, that is to manhood shame,
So hard it is to be a womans slaue.
Such is the crueltie of womenkynd,
Now is the time, that I vntimely must
It is so hapned, that the heauens vniust,
What right is it, that he should thraldome find,
It is no lesse beseeming well, to beare
Both worthie is for to be sewd vnto,
What now is left Clarinda? what remaines,
And where is he thy Lord, and how far hence?
And is he vanquisht by his tyrant enemy?
Is broken with some fearefull dreames affright,
That he is not the while in state to woo;
That this is things compacte betwixt you two,
Nought is on earth more sacred or diuine,
That part of Iustice, which is Equity,
Ne drinke of wine, for wine they say is blood,
Such is the powre of that same fruit, that nought
That by your change of cheare is easie for to see.
The righteous Knight, that is thy faithfull louer.
For that same Crocodile Osyris is,
Ah my deare Lord, what sight is this (quoth she)
Where is that dreadfull manly looke? where be
Then farewell fleshly force; I see thy pride is nought.
Since neither is endamadg'd much thereby.
That is a mayden Queene of high renowne,
There is a mighty man, which wonnes here by
He is prouokt, and stird vp day and night
That is berobbed of her youngling dere,
Is so exceeding furious and fell,
Is wondrous strong, and hewen farre vnder ground
And all within, it full of wyndings is,
This well I wote, that sure she is as great,
So much more then is that of powre and art,
As it is greater prayse to saue, then spill,
Is liker lingring death, then loathed life to bee.
And forced it, the honour that is dew
What else they haue, is all the Tyrants fee;
That right long time is ouerborne of wrong,
That same is it, which fought for you this day.
That is the vertue selfe, which her reward doth pay.
What is there else (sayd he) left of their rout?
Full deadly wounds, where so it is empight;
Is with the blast of some outragious storme
Whiles she alone is left, and thou here found?
Or is she thrall, or doth she not suruiue?
But by that Tyrant is in wretched thraldome bound.
To whom he thus; My name is Burbon hight,
Is mine owne loue, though me she haue forlore,
That is the greatest shame and foulest scorne,
True is, that I at first was dubbed knight
For she by force is still fro me detayned,
And with corruptfull brybes is to vntruth mis-trayned.
Hard is the case, the which ye doe complaine;
Your honours stile, that is your warlike shield.
To temporize is not from truth to swerue,
Knights ought be true, and truth is one in all:
Sayd Artegall; What foule disgrace is this,
To blot your beautie, that vnblemisht is,
Is ought on earth so pretious or deare,
As prayse and honour? Or is ought so bright
Fie on the pelfe, for which good name is sold,
Dearer is loue then life, and fame then gold;
Whose nature is to grieue, and grudge at all,
Whose sight to her is greatest crosse, may fall,
Of all that pleasant is to eare or eye,
Then is the bloosme of comely courtesie,
That it indeed is nought but forgerie,
Yet is that glasse so gay, that it can blynd
The wisest sight, to thinke gold that is bras.
But vertues seat is deepe within the mynd,
Yet so from low to high vplifted is your fame.
Which of all goodly manners is the ground,
What is that quest (quoth then Sir Artegall)
What is that Blattant Beast? (then he replide)
It is a Monster bred of hellishe race,
That surely is that Beast (saide Calidore)
Is not occasiond through my misdesert,
This Castle, is by name Briana hight.
His name is Crudor, who through high disdaine
Shall driue a Mill, within strong bancks is pent,
So soone as passage is vnto him lent,
Bloud is no blemish; for it is no blame
Bloud is no blemish; for it is no blame
And is the boast of that proud Ladies threat,
For nothing is more blamefull to a knight,
All flesh is frayle, and full of ficklenesse,
To pay each with his owne is right and dew.
What vertue is so fitting for a knight,
Great skill it is such duties timely to bestow.
For euerie thing, to which one is inclin'd,
He now againe is on his former way,
In blood of knight, the which by thee is slaine,
But sith that he is gone irreuocable,
